description:
Cryptosporidium parvum Iowa II is a protozoan parasite that belongs to the phylum Apicomplexa. It is a species of Cryptosporidium, a genus of parasitic protozoans that can infect a wide range of vertebrate hosts, including humans.

Cryptosporidium parvum Iowa II is a genotype or subtype of the species Cryptosporidium parvum, which is one of the most common and well-studied species of Cryptosporidium. The "Iowa II" designation refers to the specific genetic strain or subtype that was isolated from a waterborne outbreak in Iowa, United States.

C. parvum Iowa II is a small, single-celled organism that is capable of infecting the intestinal epithelial cells of its host. It has a complex life cycle that involves the formation of environmentally resistant oocysts, which can be transmitted through contaminated water, food, or direct contact with infected individuals or animals.

Infection with C. parvum Iowa II can cause the disease cryptosporidiosis, which is characterized by diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea, and vomiting. The illness is particularly severe in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS, and can be life-threatening in some cases.

Cryptosporidium parvum Iowa II is an important public health concern, as it has been responsible for numerous waterborne outbreaks of cryptosporidiosis worldwide. Understanding the biology, epidemiology, and molecular characteristics of this parasite is crucial for developing effective preventive and control measures.
